marc:datafield.marc:subfield: In hoc corpore continentur tripertite historie ex Socrate Sozomeno et Theodorico in vnu[m] collecte et nuper de Greco in Latinu[m] translate libri numero duodecim.
Per Iohanne[m] Schüssler regie vrbis Augustensis ciuem q[ua]m dilige[n]ter impressi,
anno salutifere Incarnationis Christi Hiesu [1472], circiter Nonas Februarias [5 Feb.]
Imprint from colophon (leaf [v]4r), which gives date in Latin words.
The first leaf and the last 2 leaves are blank.
Folger copy: last leaf, blank, lacking; edges have been trimmed, affecting manuscript notes.

Large initial on leaf [a]2r in blue paint with red penwork infill; smaller initials in red or blue, alternating irregularly; paragraph marks and capital strokes added in red throughout; headlines added mostly in red.
Extensive manuscript notes in several hands.

Ownership inscription at head of leaf [a]2r: "Ad Bibliothecam FF: min: Sc. Franc: Conuent[us] Ratisbon[a]e"; autograph "Hugh Penfold 1887" on verso of front free endpaper (no. 570 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, March 1911); bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.
Conclusiones de diversis materiis moralibus, sive De regulis mandatorum
Secuntur co[n]clusiones de diuersis materijs moralib[us] vtiles /
valde posite p[er] m[a]g[ist]r[u]m Ioha[n]nem de Gersona doctorem eximiu[m] in theologia ac ca[n]cellariu[m] ecclesie Beate Marie Parysiens[is].
Woodcut capitals and 2 capital spaces (1 of them with guide letter).
Folger copy: last leaf, blank, lacking.
Pencilled mark "Dpl" at head of recto of 1st leaf.

Copy 2. Blank [1]₁ wanting. Paragraph marks, initials in red (principal initial space on p. [5] left blank). No paging in table of contents or text, except for foliation in modern pencil which does not take leaf [1]₁ into account. Quire [1] does not appear to contain cancel. Quire [9] is entirely printed, without any leaves in ms. Leaf [25]₉ (recto) ends correctly "vt patet." The last line of [41]₂ (recto) is supplied in manuscript, but in a different hand from that used in the same place in LC copy 1. Leaf [41]₃ (recto) is a corrected state, having printed the correction found in manuscript in LC copy 1. Ms. inscription at head of leaf [3]: Monasterij S. Faelicitatis in [?].
Sermones aurei de sanctis Fratris Leonardi de Vtino, sacre theologie doctoris, ordinis Predicato[rum]
Abbey of St. Ulrich and Afra,

Explicit: Expliciunt Sermo[n]es aurei de s[an]c[t]is p[er] totu[m] a[n]num, quos co[m]pilauit magister Leonhardus de Vtino, sacre theologie doctor Ordinis Fratrum P[re]dicatorum, ad insta[n]tia[m] & co[m]place[n]tia[m] magnifice comunitatis Vtinensis ac nobilium virorum eiudem [sic] Mccccxlvi in vigilia beatissimi patris nostri Dominici ...
Place of publication and publisher statement from Goff; date of publication from colophon.

Folger copy lacks leaves [1]1 (blank), [2]2, [3]3-8, [6]4, [8]10, [9]3-8, [10]5,6, [18]4,7, [19]4-7, [23]5,6, [28]3, [32]5,6, [37]2, 8-10, [38]1-4, [44]8, [45]7 (collation verified with LC copy Incun. 1474. L48 BX1756; leaves [12]1,8 being disjunct, do not allow to verify that leaf [12]8 is a cancel); edges trimmed affecting manuscript quiring.
Initials, paragraph marks and underlining of titles of sermons provided in red paint throughout (with more extensive rubrication in "In festo Visitationis gloriose virginis Marie").
Manuscript quiring in brown ink; a few corrections in text.

Bookplate with motto "Torcular calcavi solus" of John Patrice Auguste Madden; booklabel of George Dunn, his initials, date "May 1897" and notes on front flyleaf (no. 3862 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, Nov. 1917); a small purple stamp with initials "HH" in a circle and a triangle, at foot of recto of last leaf, unidentified; bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

Previously bound in a later cardboard binding covered with 3 layers of different paste papers, with early printed fragments used as endpaper and spine reinforcement; rebound; in a tailored box (paste papers and printed waste kept in a container in the box).
St. Ulrich und Afra (Benedictine abbey : Augsburg, Germany),
De angelorum et obsequio [et] custodia, ac de filiorum correctione notatu [et] dignissima [et] vtilissima.
anno salutifere ... Natiuitatis D[omi]ni nostri I[es]u [Christ]i 1498 ... impressu[m] est ...
Place of publication and publisher statement from Goff; date of publication from colophon (leaf a6r).
Small woodcut on t.p. depicting an angel.
Folger copy: edges trimmed, slightly affecting signatures.
Alum tawed finding tab on last leaf.

Ad reuerendissimum in [Christ]o patrem et dominum B. miseratione diuina sancte Romane Ecclesie dignissimum Episcopum Cardinalem Sabinensem Placentinum ... fratris Iacobi Florentini Ordinis Minorum prefatio in sequens opus fratris Raijnerij de Pisis ordinis Predicatorum incipit.
Title from caption on leaf [a]2r (1st pt.).
Leaves [D]12 and [a]1 in v. 1, and [a]1 and [2z]8 in v.2, are blank.

Folger copy: v.1: table bound at end of the vol.; leaf [D]12, blank, lacking; leaves [z]4-7 misbound, reading [z]5, [z]4, [z]7, [z]6; v.2 lacks leaves [a]1 (blank), [a]2, and [2z]8 (blank); leaf [a]9 misbound before [a]3; conjugate leaves [l]4-[l]7 duplicated in gathering [l] of vol. 2.

Illuminated initials on leaves [a]2r and [a]3r with acanthus ornament extending in the margin, in colors with punched gold background; initial on leaf [a]3r in frame painted in alternate red and green; large initials crudely painted in color in v. 2; initials, capital strokes, and underlining of first word of sentences in red paint throughout; inscription "nullus defectus" in same red paint in first blank column on leaf [z]5v (another blank column on leaf [2l]4v has these words printed).

Omissions in text supplied in manuscript at foot of columns; numerous manuscript notes in margins in several hands (and some short notes of commentary), with fists, numbering, underlining, and trefoil markings used as signes-de-renvoi; a few corrections in text; some manuscript notes point at the misbinding in gathering [3] in v. 1; manuscript numbering of leaves, reading "1-985" including missing leaf [a]2 at beginning of v. 2; manuscript table on back flyleaf of v. 1 giving leaf no. of each table of contents; manuscript addition of leaf no. to chapters in tables of contents throughout the 2 vols.

Several ownership inscriptions "Mon[aste]rij Montis S. Georgij" [for the Benedictines of Sankt Georgenberg] at beginning of v. 1 and at end of v. 2, with dates 1659 and 1652; bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

In a contemporary Augsburg calf binding, originally on wooden boards, blind tooled with floral stamps, "ave Maria" inscription and symbol of St. John the Evangelist (cf. Kyriss 27, and Schwenke-Schunke Evangelisten-Symbole 3a, Schrift 192 etc. "Augsburg Schwinck-Meister"); remains of 2 clasps; paper label with handwritten author name and title on front cover of each volume; inscriptions on lower edges reading from spine to fore-edge "Prima pars pantheologie" and "Secã ps. pan."; leather tabs on 1st leaf of each table of contents; vellum fragments used as reinforcement in most of the gatherings; rebound in 1990 and 1991, retaining original leather; clasps repaired (original wooden boards kept and shelved with the book).

cum figuris et ymaginibus ab inicio mu[n]di vsq[ue] nu[n]c temporis.

Folger copy includes 2-page map of northern and central Europe with Latin type-set captions and descriptions, bound between text and table.

Washington, D.C., Folger Shakespeare Library, 1992-1993. New World of Wonders (catalog entry 8)

A few early manuscript notes in brown ink in several hands, with underlining.

Early handwritten inscriptions on t.p.: "Pret: 17s."; "Gulielmus Johnsonn me inretenet", "John Richardson", and "Robert Tomlison"; another handwritten inscription on front pastedown, defaced "J. Nicholls"; pictorial bookplate "Sir John Smith, Bart.", with coat of arms and motto "Semper fidelis".
Purchased in 1928 according to Mrs. Folger's files.
Folger copy: a few brackets and fists in brown ink.
In a half leather binding with marble paper sides.
Hoc opus exactu[m] diuina arte Ioannis Amerbacensis ...,
anno salutiferi Virginalis Partus [1490] Idibus Februarijs [13 Feb.]
Commentary by Thomas Wallensis and Nicholas Trivet.

Imprint from colophon (leaf O4r), which reads: Hoc opus exactũ diuina arte Ioannis Amerbacensis: lector vbiqz legas. Inuenis in textu glosis seu margine mi[rum]: Quo merito gaudet vrbs Basilea dec[us]. Anno salutiferi virginalis partus nonagesimo supra millesimũ quaterqz centesimũ Idibus februarijs.
The day and month in the colophon are doubtless taken over from Amerbach's edition of 1489.
Signatures: a¹⁰, b-p⁸, q-x⁶/⁸, y⁶, A-K⁸/⁶, L-O⁶/⁸.
Text printed in 2 columns, surrounded by commentary.
Large woodcut on leaf a1v, depicting Augustine and the cities of God and Satan.
Folger copy: initial painted in gold and colors on leaf a4r.

Larger capitals supplied in red and blue (with penwork extension on leaves a2r, a3r and a4r) smaller capitals in alternate red and blue throughout the book; paragraph marks in red or blue, some underlining and brackets in red; a few notes in same red paint, in upper or lower margin on leaves a7r-a8v, a9v-a10v, b1v-b2r.
Manuscript notes, underlining, fists and brackets in brown ink.
In a later sheepskin binding, blind tooled with garland, Greek key design rolls, and multiple fillet border; repaired.
Bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

Initials in alternate red and blue (some of the woodcut initials are also rubricated); initial on leaf [y]6v with drawing, margin extension and red penwork infill; paragraph marks in alternate red and blue in the table of contents and in text in the 1st gatherings; capital strokes in red in the same gatherings; additions of headlines in same red paint with numbering of sermons in gatherings [e] to [h].

A few early manuscript notes in brown ink; numbering of sermons added by hand on recto of each leaf; fists, mostly in the 1st chapter of sermon 26, with addition of headline "De extremo iudicio ser. xxvi".

Top of leaf [a]1, bearing inscription (mark of ownership?), has been cut out; early inscriptions on leaf [a]1r "... liber mgr̃i Io' Benckelnj [...?] quond[am] plebam [...?]", and "Ex Bib monarij Amor. Ord. S. Benedicti"; bookstamp "Fürstl. Leining. Hof-Bibliothek"; pencilled note on front flyleaf referring to the Sotheby sale of 24 Feb. 1898 (no. 160 in the sale catalog of the Canon W.R. Churton at that date); bookplate of Charles Butler (no. 653 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, April 1911); bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

Contemporary brown sheepskin German binding blind tooled, with brass bosses, edge guards and remains of fluted clasps; stamps of the symbols of the 4 Evangelists, pierced heart, rosettes, and fleur-de-lis. Cf. Fine and historic bookbindings from the Folger Shakespeare Library, 10:1; conjugate leaves x1-x8, x4-x5, and y1-y6 bear impression of a damp coarse linen cloth centered over the text; manuscript fragments used as pastedowns; vellum guards inside of some gatherings; repaired; in a tailored box.

Redgrave Muswell Hill 1883", with his bibliographic notes, signed "G.R.R." on front free endpaper; also a code or shelfmark on front pastedown.

Ancille p[rae]no[m]i[n]ati presbiteri dederu[n]t hoc volume[n] domui Castrim[ar]ie ord[inis] carthusien[sis] anno millesimo ccccco."; bookplate of Robert Buchanan Stewart with monogram and motto "Ubi thesaurus ibi cor", and his bibliographical notes on back pastedown (no. 1044 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, Apr. 1888); bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

In a contemporary North German calf binding from Westphalia, blind tooled with fleur-de-lis, lamb, pelican etc. (See Schwenke-Schunke Lilie 204, Schrift 129, etc.) Cf. Fine and historic bookbindings from the Folger Shakespeare Library, 1:5; 2 clasps (one of them missing, the other repaired); evidence of leather finding tabs at beginning of each book and of index; 2nd compartment of spine painted red with title inscription in black ink; in a tailored box containing fragments of one original clasp.

A recension of the Auctoritates Aristotelis, with many changes.

Reprinted from the ed. of F. de Benedictis, 1 April 1495, the date in the colophon being unchanged. Cf. BM 15th cent.
Capital spaces, with guide letters on leaves a2r and a3r.

Folger copy: early manuscript notes in brown ink, marks, brackets, fists, underlining, and a few drawings; a few corrections in text and filling of unevenly printed letters in same ink; signature, lacking on leaf c2r, has been added by hand in another ink.

Inscriptions "Marchionj Badensj, primogenito", and "321" in brown ink on t.p.; in margins of dedicatory letter to Jakob, Margrave of Baden (1471-1511) and of the "Endecasyllabon ad Germaniam" at end of the book, several notes, the last one reading "Dño meo marchionj"; underlining in red ink on t.p., and addition in same ink of "2c[us][?]" at end of the inscription of the name of the dedicatee; inscription on front flyleaf "H.C. Hoskier Dec. 1902" (no. 245 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, June 1908); his provenance and binding prices (?) have been erased; bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

anno Salutis [1495] octauo Idus Nouembres [6 Nov.] ...
With additions by Marcus Antonius Aldegatus.
Imprint from colophon (leaf Q4r), which expresses date in Latin words.
Capital spaces, mostly with guide letters.
A few early manuscript notes and a fist in brown ink.
Ownership inscription on leaf Q3v, defaced, illegible; bookplate of Eduardo J. Bullrich; purchased in 1960.
Sextus Iulius Frontinus uir consularis De re militari. Flauius Vegetius uir illustris De re militari. Aelianus De instruendis aciebus. Modesti Libellus de uocabulis rei militaris.
Impressit omni solertia Plato de Benedictis Bononiensis in alma ciuitate Bononiae,
Edited by Joannes Sulpitius Verulanus and Filippo Beroaldo. The authors collected here are from those traditionally known as Scriptores rei militaris.

Frontinus' work is known as Stratagematica; Vegetius' work is commonly titled De re militari; Aelianus' work, written in Greek, is known by the Latin title Tactica; the De vocabulis rei militaris, passing under the name of one Modestus, is believed to have been copied from Vegetius in the 15th cent.
In 4 pts., each one dated: I) 10 July 1495; II) 16 Nov. 1495; III) [n.d.]; IV: [n.d.]; place of publication and publisher statement from general colophon (leaf 2R5v), which is dated: 17 Jan. 1496.
Diagrams of military tactical formations are created by the use of ordinary printer's types arranged in patterns showing the positioning of troops.
Folger copy: a few early manuscript notes in brown ink in parts of the book, with brackets and paragraph marks.

A typed description of the book, emphasizing a chapter of medical interest in Vegetius, pasted on a clipping from a bookseller catalog in Italian on front pastedown; gift of Robert M. Smith (Aug. 14, 1951).
In a later vellum binding; inner margin stained in a few gatherings; two blank corners of the 1st leaf cut off without loss of text; manuscript fragment used as reinforcement around last gathering.

Contemporary Italian sheepskin binding, blind tooled, with 5 quadrangular ropework knot stamps in central panel, S-tool border and intricate ropework border on both covers; crisscross stamp on spine; also a later spine label in paper with inscription of author, title, imprint, and shelfmarks "4966", and "714" (in a different ink); inscription on lower edge "opusc:la D. Bernardi" reading from spine to fore-edge; original vellum pastedowns are now free; some worming; rebacked; in a tailored box.

"Here beginnen the reuelacio[n]s of Saynt Elysabeth the kynges doughter of hungarye,", caption title, p5v. It is a translation of the "Revelationes Sanctae Elizabethae Hungariae", sometimes attributed to Saint Elizabeth of Hungary or to Elizabeth of Toess, and misattributed to Jacobus Montanus (see Halkett & Laing (3rd ed., 1980), p. 94 and "The Library" 14 (March 1992), p. 1-11).
Colophon begins "Here enden the reuelacions of saynt Elysabeth the kynges doughter of hungarye ..". For a later issue see STC 24766.3.
Identified as STC 24768 in UMI microfilm reel guide.

HH53/11. Imperfect: leaves 2A1-2A2, 2A4 wanting, supplied in ms.; parts of 'tabula' supplied in ms.; leaf v5 torn, affecting text; some leaves frayed and repaired; stained. Manuscript notes in brown ink throughout the volume; tipped in at front are: a leaf containing bibliographical information about the volume signed by George Bullen of the British Museum and 2 letters from Bullen to Sir Walter Elliott, all dated 1876; advertisement for "Caxton Commemoration Volume" with facsimile of a leaf of the Dits des philosophes, 1477 ed., inserted at end of the volume. In a later goatskin binding. Provenance: autographs in colophon: "James Scott writer in Jedburgh 29 July 1747" and "Den[n]ys [...?]"; inscription on n4v: 'Robert Renwick his Book' dated 1759 (most of the notes are in his hand); letter tipped in at front from previous owner William Oliver to 'Sir Walter Elliott K.C.S.I. of Wolfelee, Hawick', dated January 1874, offers speculation about other former owners; Sotheby sale, 29-30 April 1920:433; collated by Max Privett at Quaritch, 5 May 1920; George Henderson - William Oliver - Sir Walter Elliott - Harmsworth copy

HH53/12. Imperfect: wanting gathering 2A and leaves k2-3, t1,6; stained; some leaves torn and repaired. MS. notes in margins, sometimes cropped; MS. markings; words 'pope' and 'Thomas of Canterbury' crossed out in red pencil. In a later calf binding. Provenance: inscriptions: on a41r: 'John Wills [or Wiles?]; on s5v: 'Wiliam Whit'; on I4v: 'Thys his Thom p[er]kyns booke'; on front pastedown is printed label with shelfmark added in brown ink: 'Case B Shelf 13'; bookplate of Earl of Roden; Harmsworth copy

Ownership inscription on leaf a2r: Can: Reg: Mon[aste]rij Waldsee.

Contemporary pigskin binding, blind tooled with stamps of phoenix, lamb and the 4 Evangelists' symbols (Kyriss 162) from Weissenau. Cf. Schwenke-Schunke Evangelisten-Symbole 39, Lamm 74, Phönix 2, Schrift 324. Evidence of 2 clasps; manuscript vellum fragments used as spine reinforcement and guards; handwritten shelfmark "3 3063" and inscription "Bartholoma[eus] Anglicus De proprietatibus" on spine; some worming; repaired; in a tailored box; too fragile to microfilm.

Extensive manuscript notes in several hands in text and commentary, in brown and red inks; notes in red paint with some rubrication in parts of the book, mostly capital strokes and underlining; corrections and additions in text; addition of a line of text on leaves C6v and C7r in brown ink; in several scenes of Act III of Andriae, replicas are numbered in text and translated into English in the margins (early handwriting); a later note on leaf e4r refers to J. Lipsius' De Cruce and 1662 ed. of a work by J. Praetorius; leaves 5-205 numbered by hand "1-200"; beginning of a manuscript index on last leaf in same hand; a few woodcuts partially handcolored.

[R]euerendissimi domini Archiep[iscop]i Flore[n]tini Beati Antonini ordi[ni]s P[rae]dicato[rum] uiri utrius[que] pagine p[er]itissimi, Tractat[us] super ce[n]suras, feliciter incipit.
The 1st separate ed. of this text, which consists of titles 24-29, chapter I of the 3rd pt. of the Summa theologica of Saint Antoninus. Cf. BM 15th cent.

Folger copy: initials rubricated in red and blue, alternating irregularly (errors in rubrication of a few initials have been corrected); headings provided in same red paint with a few paragraph marks; also rubrication in different red inks (capital strokes, a few brackets, paragraph marks, and occasional marginalia).
Unidentified coat of arms painted in lower margin, on leaf [a]2r.
Aureola ex floribus S. Hieronymi contexta

Hec sunt rubrice quaternionu[m] Flosculoru[m] & Transitus Sancti Hyeronimi doctoris eximii & Miraculoru[m] & quaru[n]dam Ep[isto]larum Sancti Augustini de laudibus Sancti Hyeronimi ad Cyrilum Ep[iscopu]m Yponensem & Cyrilii ad Augustinum.
Imp[re]ssum p[er] magistru[m] Philippum de Lauagnia i.cccc.lxxv. [i.e. 1475] die xxviii Noue[m]br.
Title from end of register (recto of last leaf).

The Aureola is the work elsewhere attributed to Lupus de Oliveto (or Olmeto) with title Regula monachorum ex Epistolis Hieronymi excerpta. Cf. B. Lambert, Bibliotheca Hieronymiana manuscripta, IIIb (Steenbrugis, 1970) no. 552; Sack, V. Freiburg, 2294. The 'editorship' of Thomas Dorniberg seems to apply only to the Speyer edition, where Dorniberg states that this selection from Jerome's writings was made by an anonymous compiler (cf. BM 15th cent., II p. 482).
Includes Vita et transitus Hieronymi (i.e. Eusebius of Cremona's Epistola de morte Hieronymi), St. Augustine's Epistola de magnificentiis Hieronymi, and St. Cyril's De miraculis Hieronymi.
Imprint from colophon (leaf [y]8r); Filippo da Lavagna was active in Milan.

Folger copy: the 1st work contains manuscript finding notes and signes-de-renvoi, most of them in red (some faded from washing of leaves) giving references to Jerome's works and letters; a few fists and notes in brown ink in the "Testamentum"; manuscript numbering of leaves throughout the book reading "1-c75" (with some errors corrected) and corresponding numbers added in manuscript to the table of the "Testamentum".

Manuscript note at foot of leaf [a]1 "Ad vsu[m] Fran[cis]ci [splti?] Laud. Pbr. amicho[rum] q[ue] nunc pbĩ Antonij Guerana eius nepotis"; autograph, notes, and prices on front free endpaper of Michael Wodhull (no. 1278 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, Jan. 1886) with his provenance "Pinelli Auction" (no. 1472 (?) in the Pinelli sale catalog, March 1789) and his dates "Apr: 18th 1789" and "Feb: 4th 1795" at beginning and at end of the book; bookplates of Charles Butler (no. 546 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, Apr. 1911) and of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.
Regula monachorum ex Epistolis Hieronymi excerpta.

Title from incipit of v. III (leaf A2r).
Folger copy includes vols. III, IV, and table by Johannes Beckenhaub only bound in 1 vol.

Table varies from copies described in Hain and in BM 15th cent., t.p. reading: "Tabula super libros sentẽ-/tia[rum] cum Bonauentura". Leaf a2r reads: "Johannes beckenhaub / moguntini in scripta Diui Bonauẽture cũ textu sen-/ tentia[rum] tabula: quã siquis ..."

The printer is named in the dedicatory letter of v. I; imprint date from v. IV; the letter of Nicolaus Tinctoris to Beckenhaub is dated: 1491 mensis Marcii die s[e]c[un]do; the table was probably printed apart and later than the rest of the book. Cf. BM 15th cent.
Signatures: v.III: A⁸, B-Z⁶, Aa-Ll⁶, Mm⁸, Nn⁴; v.IV: a-b⁸, c-z⁶, A-S⁶, T-V⁸, X⁶; table: a⁸, b-q⁶, r⁸ (in v. IV, f4 signed f5, L3 signed 3L).
First leaves of v. III and v. IV, and last leaf of table are blank.
Capital spaces, many with guide letters.
Folger copy: early manuscript notes with brackets and fists in 3 hands, one being Blasius Fünck's and another B. Pflugritter's.

Early inscription on front pastedown "Liber magistri Blasij Fůnck de Franckẽford" with his notes throughout dated "1507 in die S. Luce incepi 3m [...]" on verso of 2nd leaf of v.III; "1508 incepi lege[re] 4 [pars] Sentẽ. 2 ps̃ [...post?] matthie apos. B.F." on 2nd leaf of v. IV, and "altera die Vrbani 5. [...] an[te] d[o]m[inicam] rogationu[m] 1508 [...] M.B. Fünck sacra theo[logi]e bacc[alaureat]us [...]" at end of v. IV; his annotations throughout the 2 vols. in lower margins with brackets and markings in text (Blasius Fünck registered at the University of Leipzig in 1487); another set of notes on 1st leaves of v. III, the 1st one reading "anno 1506 [...] cepi insignia Magisterij [...] Ego bernardus pfuckritter de Forchem [for Bernardus Pflugritter who registered at the University of Leipzig in 1501] with other notes about events taking place during years 1509, 1511 and 1514; notes in same hand in v. III & IV; other notes in red and brown inks from an unidentified hand in v. IV, and on a paper fragment, loosely inserted; later inscription on 2nd leaf of v. III "Ad Bibliothecam PP. Franciscan: Ambergae" and circular bookstamp on top edge with initials "SBA".

In a contemporary pigskin binding from Leipzig (Cf. Schwenke-Schunke Blattwerk 470 and Rautengerank 103 "Leipzig Buchführer Kyriss 102/103"), with 2 clasps; manuscript fragments used as pastedowns; vellum tab bearing handwriting at head of v.IV (repaired with later paper fragment); handwritten shelfmark on spine "32" and a later leather label with author, title, and date.

Fragment contains: Book 14, ch. 15-pt. of 17; pt. of 21-pt. of 26; book 15, pt. of ch. 5-pt. of ch. 8, pt. of ch. 11-pt. of 13; book 7, ch. 17-35; book 8, ch. 1-pt. of 7; book 16, pt. of ch. 34-ch. 43; book 17, ch. 1-pt. of ch. 9.

This fragment is identifiable as the 1468 ed. through comparison with the 1470 ed. which is in a different setting; chapter headings have been left to the rubricator whereas in the 1470 ed. the headings are printed; BM 15th cent. does note in the description of IC.17140 (v. IV, p. 9) that with only one exception, works from this press that lack printed headings appeared prior to 1470.

Large initial on leaf a2r, in blue with white modeling, within a half red, half green frame, with gilt ground bearing impression of bird and flower design; initials at beginning of a few of the Books, in interlocking red and blue paint; smaller initials provided in red or blue, alternating irregularly, and capital strokes in red throughout the book; a few paragraph marks; sign of a wheel at foot of leaf a5r in same red paint.

Early manuscript notes and commentary in margins, underlining and brackets mostly in brown ink; manuscript corrections and interlineary notes in text; manuscript correction of signature on leaves r3 and O2 of headline on leaf Q3, in brown ink.

Yates and of Nell Rose Wheeler and Charles Van Cise Wheeler (no. 331 in the Walpole Galleries sale catalog of Charles Van Cise Wheeler's library, July 1919); purchased in 1919.

Later pigskin German binding blind tooled with floral and medallion borders, central panel on front cover depicting the Virgin, God and Christ; 2 brass clasps; 2 paper spine labels, one on top of the other, the top one bearing inscription in red paint and brown ink, reading "S. Biblia Lat. cum nom: Hebr. interp."; date of printing inscribed in lower pt. of spine; too fragile to be microfilmed.

Leaves [superscript pi]1, A1 and t8 blank.

Capitals provided in red throughout the book. A few fists and manuscript notes in brown ink, several of them on leaves f3-f4; a few corrections in text and of errors in headings; also an early note (or quote?) on front pastedown followed by "AP"; references (or shelfmarks?) handwritten on front endpaper one reading "7 Ss d.", the other "R[?] 8 Ss d". Original Augsburg sheepskin binding on wooden boards, blind tooled, (Kyriss 77; Schwenke-Schunke "Blattwerk 452"); 5 bosses (only 3 remain on each cover); remains of 2 clasps catching on front cover; early label at head of front cover reading "Ropert[us] Holcot sup[er] lib[er] sapiẽ."; fragment of an early paper label on spine reading "VII [...?]9:" (other inscriptions have been covered by more recent labels). Purchased in 1958.

Initials provided in red at beginning of each part, some with brown penwork infill; capital strokes and paragraph marks in red; rubrication of printed paragraph marks throughout the book; some words of text, unevenly printed are filled in with red paint; also a few reader's marks in margins, in same paint.

Early manuscript finding notes in one hand with a few drawings and markings ("Nota", "V[ide]",etc.); one of the notes refers to "Dominus suche" on leaf [o]5r; some notes point to inversion of text on leaves [s]3v and [s]6r.

Booklabel of George Dunn with his initials, date "June 1902", and bibliographic notes pencilled on front free endpaper (no. 3900 in the Sotheby sale catalog of his library, Nov. 1917); bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

In a contemporary Oxford calf binding with blind tooled decoration from the Rood and Hund bindery; central panels made of juxtaposition of square animal stamps (unicorn, double-headed eagle with a star between its heads, 2 cocks affrontés, a chalice between 2 doves, etc.) in a border made of foliage stamps; some animal stamps are repeated in the outer border; remains of 2 clasps catching on lower cover; manuscript numbering of gatherings, affected by cropping of edges; manuscript fragment sewn inside each gathering. Cf. Hobson, G. D. English bindings before 1500, pl

Numerous early finding notes in brown and red inks with additions of corrections and of punctuation in some of the sermons; a few of the corrections use a cross as a signe-de-renvoi; also numerous "nota" and other markings; numbers included in the text of some of the sermons are rubricated and repeated in the margins in red ink; damaged leaves in gatherings e and f have been repaired and lacking text added by hand in same handwriting and same ink as the notes and corrections; a longer note on leaf z2r with quotes (in a different hand); guide letters have been added by hand in capital spaces; manuscript numbering on leaves a2-M7, reading 1-250, is referred to in table of sermons on leaf a1v; markings in black pencil in a few gatherings; manuscript note about the author added to the title on t.p.

Manuscript index of vocabulary contained in the Mammotrectus, starting on leaf [*]2r and continued on 11 leaves inserted between table and text; many words listed in index at the end of the alphabet (letters s-z) have not been completed by references to chapters of the Bible; in the gathering of 10 (+1) leaves inserted, conjugate leaves 2,9 are misbound reading 1,9,3,4,5,6,7,8,2,10; index rubricated like the rest of the vol.; manuscript headlines throughout the vol. contain title of Books, in same hand as index.

Leaf a1v reads: Proemivm Platynae in Vitas Pontificvm ad Sixtvm. IIII. Pontificem Maximum.
Probably a reprint from the edition of De Colonia and Manthen, Venice, 1479, with the omission of the letter of Squarzaficus to the author and of "impressum" in the colophon.--Brit. Mus.
This book, which shows no internal connexion with Treviso, may be Venetian and date from 1485-86. The watermark of a crescent was in use in both Treviso and Venice about this time.--Brit. Mus.
Folger copy: last leaf, blank, lacking; recto of leaf k8, stained, with slight loss of text.

Preclarissimus liber elementorum Euclidis perspicacissimi, in artem geometrie incipit qua[m]foelicissime.
Erhardus Ratdolt Augustensis impressor solertissimus Venetijs impressit,
anno Salutis 1482 octauis Calen[darum] Iun[ij] [25 May]
Title from incipit in red (leaf a2r).
Also published on vellum and illuminated. Variations in the incipit, dedication, headlines in the first signature, etc. are recorded, issued with the same colophon.

Translated from Arabic by Adelard of Bath; edited by Campano da Novara. While books I-XIII are Euclid's (cf. Th. Heath. The thirteen books of Euclid's Elements. 1956, v.3, p. 519), Book XIV is a work of the 2d cent. by Hypsicles and book XV the work of a Roman land-surveyor of the 6th century. For a discussion by B.L. van der Waerden of Euclid's sources see Enc. Brit., 15th ed., Micro. IV, p 589.
With dedicatory letter by Erhard Ratdolt.

Here foloweth a lytell treatyse the whiche treateth of the descrypcyon of this londe whiche of olde tyme was named Albyon and after Brytayne and now is called Englonde and speketh of the noblenesse and worthynesse of the same

Imprint from colophon, which reads: Here endeth the descrypcyon of Brytayne .. therfore I haue sette the desrypcyon [sic] of the same after the sayd Brytayne, whiche I haue taken out of Polycronycon. And by cause it is necessarye to all Englysshmen to knowe the propretees co[m]modytees and meruaylles of them, therfore I William Caxton haue them sette fyrste in enprynte accordynge to the translac[i]on of Treuisa, whiche atte request of the lorde Barkeley translated the boke of Polycronycon in to Englysshe. Fynysshed and enprynted at Westmestre by me Wynken de worde, the yere of our lorde a. M.CCCC. and foure score and .xviij.
Generally considered pt. II of Saint Albans chronicle, STC 9996.

HH53/12. MS. notes at end of colophon. Stained; some leaves torn and repaired. Bound as part 2 of STC 9996 copy 2. Provenance: inscriptions below colophon on D6r: 'Thys his Thom p[er]kyns booke' and 'Jhon Stowe yoman of the W [?]'; on front pastedown is printed label with shelfmark added in brown ink: 'Case B Shelf 13'; bookplate of Earl of Roden; Harmsworth copy

HH53/11. Imperfect: wanting leaves C1, C3-4, D4-6, all supplied in MS.; some leaves frayed and repaired; stained. Some ms. notes in margins: tipped in at front are: a leaf containing bibliographical information about the volume signed by George Bullen of the British Museum and 2 letters from Bullen to Sir Walter Elliott, all dated 1876. Bound as part 2 of STC 9996 copy 1. Provenance: inscription on C5v: 'Robert Renwick this belongs to 1759'; letter tipped in at front from previous owner William Oliver to 'Sir Walter Elliott K.C.S.I. of Wolfelee, Hawick', dated January 1874, offers speculation about other former owners; Sotheby sale, 29-30 April 1920:433; collated by Max Privett at Quaritch, 5 May 1920; George Henderson - William Oliver - Sir Walter Elliott - Harmsworth copy
Prohemye grete thankynges lawde and honoure we merytoryously ben bounde to yelde and offre vnto wryters of hystoryes
Grete thankynges lawde and honoure we merytoryously ben bounde to yelde and offre unto wryters of hystoryes
Syth the tyme that the grete and high tonr of babilone was bylded
By Ranulf Higden. An English translation by John Trevisa. Edited and with a continuation by William Caxton. All three individuals are named on a3v.
Caxton's continuation is reprinted from "The chronicles of England", STC 9991.

Colophon (referring to the preparation of the text) reads: ... ended the second day of Iuyll the xxij yere of the regne of kynge Edwardthe [sic] fourth [and] of the Incarnacion of oure lord a thousand four honderd foure score and tweyne, fynysshed per Caxton.

Opening of text, a2r: "Prohemye gRete thankynges lawde [and] honoure we merytoryously ben bounde to yelde and offre vnto wryters of hystoryes ..."; "1"2r: "sYth the tyme that the grete and high tonr [sic] of babilone was bylded ...".
The first leaf and the last leaf are blank.
"1"1,5, chi2 blank. L copy filmed on UMI "Tract supplement" reel E1 (Harl. 5919[149]): leaf CCClxxxxi only.
Ricci, S. de. Census of Caxtons

HH112/4. Imperfect: lacking leaves a1-8, C1-4, chi2, '49'4, '52'7-8 and gatherings '53'-'55'. Initials and paragraphs rubricated. Contemporary MS. notes and markings, including fists; some in red ink. Blind stamped sheepskin? binding, with suede and metal clasps and paper spine label; housed in red morocco case made by Riviere & Son. Provenance: inscriptions on '1'1r: "Willim [William] [Rothewill?]"; on b1r: "Liber Josephi Singer"; on '1'1r: "Jo: Singer Book"; MS. paper spine label reads: "Caxton. Mr. Horwood."; Harmsworth copy
Cap[itu]la prime partis, Here begynnen the chapytours of this present volume of Waltere Hylton, namyd in laten Scala perfecc[i]onis, englisshed the ladder of perfecc[i]on

Envoi and colophon, leaf following s4, read: .. and Wynkyn de Worde this hath sett in prynt in Willyam Caxstons hows .. Finit felicit[er] liber intitulatus Scala perfeccionis inpressus a[n]no salutis· M.cccc.lxxxxiiii.

"Here begynneth the table of the thyrde booke of Water [sic] Hylton named Vita mixta or scala perfeccionis", caption title, A1r. This book is lacking in most copies; its presence may constitute a later state.
Signatures: Signatures: a⁴ b-q⁸ r⁶ s⁴ chi1 A⁸ B⁶. Gathering m mis-signed 'k'.

Imperfect: wanting gathering a, supplied in facsimile; wanting Book 3 (all after chi1) wanting. Leaf b1 inlaid. Repaired at margins, slightly affecting text. In a Russia leather binding with gold tooling. Provenance: Autograph on leaf s5r "Jone Clarke" and inscription in same handwriting on leaf q8r "I prey for the Rev[?] Jone Stafforton"; armorial bookplate of William Horatio Crawford (motto "durum patientia frango"); Britwell Court copy (with MS. pencilled note "Britwell sale May 1920:254"); collated by Max Privett at Quaritch, 26 May 1920; Harmsworth copy

Moost vertuouse hystorye of the deuoute and right renommed lyues of holy faders
The title is xylographic (white on black).

Colophon reads: Thus endyth the moost vertuouse hystorye of the deuoute [and] right renommed lyues of holy faders .. translated out of Frensshe in to Englysshe by Wyllyam Caxton of Westmynstre late deed, and fynysshed it at the last daye of his lyff. Enprynted in the sayd towne of Westmynstre be my Wynkyn de Worde the yere of our lorde .M.CCCC.lxxxxv. and the tenth yere of our souerayne lorde kyng Henry the seuenth.
Signatures: 2A⁸ a-o⁸ p⁶ q-x⁸ y¹⁰ z-2t⁸ 2v-2x⁶.

Prologue, 2A2r, begins: Here foloweth the right deuoute, moche lowable, [and] reco[m]mendable lyff of the olde auncyent holy faders hermytes, late translated out of latyn in to frenshe, and dylygently corrected in the cyte of lyon, ye yere of our lord. M.CCCC.lxxxvi. vpon that whiche hath be wryten and also translated out of Greke in to Latyn, by the blessyd [and] holy saynt Saynt Ierome .. [and] other solytarye relygyouse persones after hy[m] and after in the yere of our lorde .M.CCCC.lxxxxi. reduced in to Englysshe ..
There are variants of 2A1, q2.7, and the colophon. "One L copy has some leaves reprinted c. 1529 w. a woodcut of about that date"--STC.

HH123/19. Made-up copy; leaf 2x6 (with title woodcut and Caxton's device) supplied in facsimile. 16C ms. inscription on 2f8v "This[?] Indent[u]r[e] [m?]ade the viijth day of July." Modern blind-tooled calf binding. Provenance: inscription on 2A2r: "Liber Robart [Boys?]"; bookplate of the Huth library (no. 7816 in the Sotheby sale catalog of the Hugh collection, July 1919); Harmsworth copy; purchased in 1938.
Translated from the Latin by John Trevisa in 1398.
Sometimes erroneously attributed to Bartholomaeus de Glanvilla.
Caption title, A2r: Prologue of the translatour. True it is· that after the noble [and] experte doctryne ...
Imprint from STC; the last leaf contains William Caxton's device, and on the verso a repetition of the t.p.

cs324. Imperfect: leaves A1-5, B1-2, B7-8, b4, part of e3, e8, f1, m4, p1, s7, t2, t7, v3, [con]8, A1, F8, G1, G8, K5, S7, T3, 2f3, 2o1-2o6 lacking, supplied in facsimile; A6, blank, lacking; from leaf i8 to leaf D4, central part of most leaves damaged and repaired, with loss of text on many leaves; last leaf (in facsimile) inserted with Caxton's device on verso; edges trimmed, affecting manuscript notes and ownership inscriptions. Early manuscript notes in English in brown ink throughout the book, repeating text in margins, in several hands; a few corrections in text. Previously bound in rough calf, probably in Oxford ca. 1600, with hatching on spine and initials "G B" stamped on boards; rebound in 1965 in quater morocco binding with green cloth sides. Provenance: MS. notes and inscriptions: Thom. Hood, Thomas Hillyard, Richard [?]; bookplate: 'Bateman of Middleton Hall (by Youlgrave) in the County of Derby'; J.O. Halliwell-Phillipps copy

HH138/30. Wormed, affecting title, t.p. woodcut, and text; trimmed, affecting some head-lines and ms. marginal notes. Early manuscript notes of contents in margins in brown ink; other notes at end of the text. Rebound in gold-tooled red goatskin in 1959; previously bound in 19th cent. calf; stamped on spine "Lyndewode Wynkyn de Worde". Provenance: number 91 in Sotheby sale catalog, July 28, 1919; Harmsworth copy; purchased in 1938.

Colophon reads: Thus endeth the lege[n]de named in latyn Legenda aurea .. whiche werke I dyde accomplisshed [sic] at the commaundeme[n]te and requeste of the noble and puyssaunte Erle [and] my specyal good Lord Wyllyam Erle of Arondel, And now hane [sic] renewed [and] fynysshed it at Westmestre the xx day of May, The yere of our Lord MCCCClxxxxiii, And in the viii yere of the reygne off Kynge Henry the vii, by me Wyllyam Caxton.

Here begynneth the prologue or prohemye of the book callid Caton :

whiche booke hath ben translated in to Englysshe by Mayster Benet Burgh, late Archedeken of Colchestre and hye chanon of Saint Stephens at Westmestre ... and by cause of late cam to my hand a book of the said Caton in Frensshe, whiche reherceth many a fayr lernynge and notable ensamples, I haue translated it oute of Frensshe in to Englysshe, as al along here after shalle appiere, whiche I presente vnto the cyte of London
The original Latin text of the Disticha, with an anonymous prose paraphrase and commentary.
The disticha, wrongly attributed to Marcus Porcius Cato, in fact date from imperial times.
Printer's name from STC; publication date from Needham.

Colophon reads: Here fynyssheth this present book whiche is sayd or called Cathon translated oute of Frensshe in to Englysshe by William Caxton in thabbay of Westmynstre the yere of oure Lord M CCCC lxxxiij, and the fyrst yere of the regne of Kynge Rychard the Thyrd the xxiij day of decembre.
Signatures: pi⁶ (pi2,3 signed ij, iij respectively) a-h⁸ i¹⁰.

HH48/27. Imperfect: wanting leaves 1 (blank), 2, and 6 and 7 (both blank) (title supplied from ESTC); blank leaf inserted at a later time between 1st and 2nd gathering. Some initials in red. Russia leather binding. Early manuscript notes in margins giving a summary at the beginning of many paragraphs; on leaf a3v, a few lines about worship of images are crossed out in brown ink; large markings at head of a few Disticha; manuscript letter on blank leaves at end of the book with title "the queenes answere to the [blank]" in another early hand; a manuscript note in colophon, defaced "In Anno Domini i609 the xxiii dey[?] of december[?] This book is CCLxxiiii years old[?]". Provenance: Pencilled note referring to Sotheby sale on front free endpaper (no. 33 in the sale catalog of William H. Ingilby's library, Oct. 1920); Harmsworth copy.

Revised and edited by William Caxton.

Leicester Harmsworth copy; shelfmark "29. D." handwritten in red ink on front pastedown; purchased in 1938.
The abbaye of the Holy Ghoost.
Here begynneth a matere spekynge of a place that is named the Abbay of the Holy Ghost ...
Sometimes erroneously attributed to John Alcock. Cf. STC; for various suggestions as to authorship, all rejected, see Halkett and Laing, 3rd ed., A3.

Incipit: Sphaerae mondi [sic] compe[n]dium foeliciter inchoat. Following that is a statement of the contents of this ed.: ... Ioa[n]nis de Sacro Busto Sphaericu[m] opusculu[m] una cu[m] additio[n]ibus no[n]nullis l[itte]ra A sparsim ubi i[n]tersertae sint signatis, Co[n]traq[ue] Cremone[n]sia i[n] planeta[rum] theoricas delyramenta Ioa[n]nis de Monteregio disputat[i]o[n]es ... nec no[n] Georgii Purbachii i[n] eoru[n]de[m] motus planeta[rum] accuratis. theoricae dicatu[m] opus ...

A page-for-page reprint of the 1490 ed. printed by Bonetus Locatellus for Octavianus Scotus (LC record 91-128020), using the same woodcut blocks. Here the color printing is less well executed, using yellowish brown ink, with the second color being a dull orange.
Folger copy 1: in a brown morocco binding, gold tooled (W. Root & Son). Purchased in 1919.

Folger copy 2: in reinforced vellum binding; edges trimmed, slightly affecting text on a few leaves. Purchased in 1919.

Title of chapters handwritten in brown at head of each leaf, presumably as part of the manufacture of the book; extensive manuscript readers notes in brown ink in several hands (one of them being Adolf Knoblauch's) with numerous fists, brackets, underlining and corrections in both text and commentary; manuscript index in A. Knoblauch's hand on front flyleaf, referring to leaf numbers; his sketches of coat of arms (one of them with garlic cloves as charges) and other notes on flyleaves and pastedowns; "Arbor consanguinitatis" reproduced by hand on back flyleaf.
Autograph "Adolfus Knobelauch Franckforter" on front flyleaf; bookstamp of the Herzogliche Öffentliche Bibliothek of Meiningen; bookplate of Mr. and Mrs. H. Dunscombe Colt.

Contemporary brown calf binding over wooden boards with blind tooled rolls and stamps (Cf. Kyriss III, no. 160 "Mainz region"; Schwenke-Schunke Schrift 210, Affe 1, etc.; Fine and historic bookbindings from the Folger Shakespeare Library, 1:1), with 2 clasps, from a secular bindery connected to the printshop of Peter Schoeffer in Mainz, according to Lotte Hellinga's article: Peter Schoeffer and the booktrade in Mainz: Evidence for the organization, in Bookbindings and other bibliophily; rebacked and repaired with sheepskin (19th cent.?); printed waste used as pastedowns, identified as recto of leaf [35] (back pastedown) and recto of leaf [36] (front pastedown) of Gregory IX's Decretales printed in Strasbourg by H. Eggestein in 1470-1472.
Gift of Mrs. H. Dunscombe Colt--1982.

In a 15th cent. alum tawed calf binding on wooden boards with 2 metal clasps (1 has remains only), woven endbands, and showing evidence of a chain attachment on top of back cover; blind tooling on boards is typical of the Nuremberg style binding (central panel of front cover shows floral pattern with stems of ornamental foliage and ragged staff, rosettes, fleur-de-lys and dragon stamps; the lower panel shows lozenge compartments in central panel with same stamps as on front cover); manuscript fragments used as paste-down endpapers have been removed from the inside of the boards, showing the remaining offset from the ink; another manuscript fragment was used as spine lining. Evidence of several spine labels; the upper one, handwritten on paper, is fragmented, revealing handwritten shelfmark on spine; also evidence of a metal framed title plaque over a horn plate on front cover. Leather tab on the 1st leaf of each book. Rebacked; in a tailored box.

Some capital spaces (a few with guide letters).

Type of text: 80 G; commentary: 63 G. Cf. BM 15th cent., I, p. 269-270 (Plate XXVII).
Woodcut on t.p. depicting a teacher and 3 students.
Folger copy: t.p. (bearing woodcut) and leaf [1st]a2 cut away (title from Vouilléme); margins trimmed, affecting manuscript notes.

Rubricated in most pts. of the 4 items bound together (initials, capital strokes on printed capitals, paragraph marks, and underlining), with a few notes in same red paint in margins; some flourishes in purple ink on the 1st leaves of the 1st item and in a few initials; some initials are figurative.

Manuscript notes throughout the vol. in brown ink, in different hands, one of them (and the rubricator's) being Johann Velchauer's whose mark of ownership appears at the end of the vol.; interlinear and marginal finding notes and numbering in another hand, with fists and blank markings throughout, and corrections in text (the notes in the last item in the vol. are dated the 3rd and 14th of February 1548 at beginning and end); manuscript music staffs of plainchant offset on the last leaf of the last item.

Ownership inscriptions defaced on the last leaf of the last item in the vol., one inscription reading: "Iste liber empt[us] compact[us] at[que] p[er]fect[us] est Viginti solidis Per me Iohannem Velchauer [defaced] anno [Christ]i xvc. [for 1515?] In Sundis"; bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

Several leaves at beginning and at end of some of the items in the vol. have been sliced at the time of cutting away of the title-pages and blank leaves, after the binding process; evidence of a leather tab on the last leaf of the 1st item; evidence of a paper tab on t.p. of the last item.

Original Italian sheep- or goatskin binding, blind tooled, with remains of a clasp on fore-edge catching on back cover, and evidence of a plate from a chain at foot of back cover; manuscript vellum fragments of statutes of a city with annotations (14th cent.?) previously used as pastedowns, at beginning and end of the book; black ink shelfmark at head of back cover "N.[?] 26"; edges stained red; rebacked.

Initials and paragraph marks rubricated in red and another color, possibly blue (now faded from washing of leaves); capital strokes in yellow at the beginning of the book.

Several inscriptions on leaf []1, defaced and faded, illegible; on verso, inscription reading "Ex libris Mag: Nath: virling [or verling?]"; inscription on front free endpaper "Coll: perf: H: Drury. Harrow. C[?] 314-2"; bookplate "From the collection of E.P. Jacobsen".
Previously in a leather 18th entury binding; major repair to the paper; rebound in limp vellum.
Luciani De ueris narrationibus ; Luciani de asino auro ...

The translations after the Vera historia are by various hands; the Palinurus attributed to Lucian is in fact the De felicitate et miseria of Maffeus Vegius; the Carmina heroica in amorem is a free translation of the 2nd Idyll of Moschus (BM 15th cent., VIII, p. 412); Virtus Dea, purporting to be a translation from Lucian by Carolus Marsupinus, is an original Latin work of Leo Battista Alberti.
Signatures: a⁸, b⁴, c-g⁸, h⁴, i-p⁸ (a2 signed a1; p2 unsigned).
Woodcut border on leaf a2r (signed a1) probably by the same artist as that of the ed. of Herodotus printed in Venice the same year.

Folger copy: manuscript notes in brown ink with a few fists, brackets, and corrections in text, in several hands (including Lodovico Ariosto's and Annibale Novelli's commentary notes); manuscript numbering of pages 3-219, reading "1-217", also added in table of contents on leaf a1r (in Ariosto's hand).

Inscription below colophon: "Ludouicus Areostus 1520"; autograph at foot of leaf a1r: "Annibalis Nouelli"; inscription at head of front pastedown "12: Ago. 1809: [̲?]4: [̲?]16:" and handwritten shelfmark "R3"; inscription on front cover "[1?]493".
Place of publication and publisher statement from colophon (leaf i4r); prefatory letter (leaf a2r) dated: decimo nono cal. Iunias. M.ccccLxxxxiii; for date see BM 15th cent.

An enlargement, completed by Nicholas of Osimo in 1444, of the Summa de casibus conscientiae by Bartholomew of San Concordio. Arranged alphabetically by topic, with the supplementary text everywhere preceded by the letter A.

Folger copy: fragment of vol. 1 only, totalling 70 leaves (description provided from BM 15th cent.).
This fragment is identifiable as the 1468 rather than 1470 ed. because the headings are not printed, but rather left to the rubricator.

Type corresponds to 115R, employed by Sweynheim and Pannartz at Rome, as described in BM 15th cent., IV, p. 4. It is not the 115R used by Arnold Pannartz for his 1476 first pt. of the Epistolae, which is distinguishable from the earlier type by a different "a", and the addition of "ȩ", alternative "i" (dotted), and of final "s" of the usual rounded kind (Cf. BM 15th cent., IV, p. 60). These characteristics are not present; moreover, the "r" has the straight shank without serif at base which did not change until the middle of 1470.

Fragment contains (identified through comparison with the Venice 1488 ed. of the Epistolae): pt. of letter 6; letters 7-8; Treatise against Jovinianus, chapters 1-28, pt. of 29, pt. of 31, 32-37, pt. of 38 and 39, chapter 40, pt. of 41; pt. of letter 11; Dialogue against the Luciferians; pt. of the Dialogue against the Pelagians; pt. of letter 18 (2 leaves); letters 23-36; pt. of letter 37; pt. of letter 86; letters 87-96; pt. of letter 97.
A few manuscript indications of interruptions in text; manuscript numbering at head of 1st leaf of each gathering.
With: Jerome, Saint. Epistolarum Beati Hieronymi pars secunda. Impressa Rome : Per ... Georgiu[m] Laur de Herbipoli, sub anno D[omi]ni 1479 die uero Lune, q[ui]nta me[n]sis Aprilis ...

"Augustinus De ciuitate Dei is the first item of Schedel's list, a position which suggests that a remainder of the 1468 ed. is there referred to rather than the present ed. On the other hand, the price (5 ducats) suits a book of 294 leaves better than one of 274 leaves, and as it has the early form of "r," it must belong to the early part of 1470 and is thus presumably early enough to be included in the list"--BM 15 cent., IV, p. 11.

A few early manuscript notes and fists in different hands; also some corrections in the text in brown ink; several sets of manuscript notes on front flyleaf, on leaf l7v and on back flyleaves (2 of them are pastedowns from the original binding), relating to the privileges confirmed by Pope Sixtus IV to the orders of the Dominicans and the Minims, and an indulgence following a mark of ownership dated 6 Jan. 1482.

Several marks of ownership: on leaf a2r, inscriptions reading "Est [Conuen]tus S. apolinaris ex[tra] muros papiã ordĩs p[rae]dica[torum]" and in a fainter ink "Est Conuentus sti Thomè Papiã" partially obliterated by circular bookstamp "Museo Cavaleri"; preceding the indulgence and other notes on pastedown from earlier binding, inscription "Mo cccc lxxxij die vj Ianuarij, Iste libellus [con]cessus est michi Frĩ Apolinari de g[...?] ad usum p. uen[e]rabilem prẽm frẽm in[no]centiu[m] de ualentia [...]".

15th century Italian goatskin binding, blind tooled with stamps of a quadrangular ropework knot and cross shaped stamps in central panels; remains of 4 brass clasps, 2 on fore-edge, 1 at head, 1 at tail (catches on back cover and a leather strap); inscription on fore-edge "Sum̃a angelica", reading from head to tail; pastedowns made of several layers of blank leaves and of later printed waste (in Italian, discussing career of arms versus scholarship as argued in Cicero, Averroës, Aristotle, etc.); repaired several times; rebacked; in a tailored box.

According to GW, the frequent ascription of the work to Panormitanus (Niccolò de' Tudeschi) is to be accepted as erroneous, although the author's name as Auerbach occurs only in the 1489 Leipzig edition (Hain 2126). Cf. Stillwell, M.B. Incunabula in American libraries, a second census, p. 53.

In a late 15th cent. pasteboard binding (alum-tawed sheep- or deerskin, reversed, stained teal blue over manuscript pasteboards of approximately 18 layers of paper manuscript); brass title plaque on lower cover (with author and title inscription); remains of 4 ties; author-title inscription repeated on all edges and on spine; strips of vellum manuscript (13th cent., a gloss to a legal text?) used as reinforcement at center of gatherings; paper coverings of pasteboards and vellum endleaves (which consist of a legal document in French, ca. 1450, concerning properties in Seine-et-Marne). Second colophon (leaf [F]8r): Sermones de tempore Alberti magni [per] Iohannem Zainer Vlme impressi Finiunt feliciter [et]c.
Place of publication and publisher statement from colophons; date of publication from Goff.

Folger copy: leaf [a]1, blank, lacking; lower edge of leaves [o]4 and [F]8 partly torn; rubricated letters are smudged at the beginning of the volume; edges trimmed affecting fore-edge inscription on front flyleaf.

Initials rubricated in red, with capital strokes, paragraph marks, and underlining of titles and biblical references; also occasional repetition of the name of the Saint in same red paint in the 1st few sermons; from leaf [s]5v on, only initials and paragraph marks are rubricated.
A few early manuscript notes in margins.

Inscription on verso of front fly leaf: Georgius Reuss de Neustadte ex Carniolana clericus Me iam suo mancipio possidet ... ; another inscription in fore-edge margin of leaf [a]2r in a different handwriting, starting: Georgius Raus ... [partially illegible]; remaining adhesive indicates a slip was pasted over it; also handwritten at head of leaf [a]2r: Bibliothecae Augustinianae ad D.V. Schuteranam Ingolstadij 1634. Viti Prieser SSae Theologiae Licentiati A.̊d. 91. Mense Ia ... [incomplete]; handwritten note on recto of front fly leaf: To L.C. Illingworth From C.B.; bookplate of W.T. Smedley; purchased in 1924.

Contemporary quarter pigskin binding, possibly Swiss, blind tooled with leaf design rolls on wooden boards; 2 clasps (1 has remains only); paper spine label at the head of the spine and small round sticker on the tail of the spine with number; inscription on fore-edge: "Postilla Alb: Magni"; the first gatherings show evidence of nail perforation from front cover, slightly affecting text; repaired; in a tailored box.
With: Paratus. Sermo[n]es Parati de te[m]pore et de Sanctis. [Passau : Johannes Petri, ca. 1487-1488]
Binding images and description for Folger Shakespeare Library INC A301
